entry.title: Re: Setting Default Values in Create-Dialog
entry.content:
Hi Max,

You can remove fields using Adapt UI configuration, so don't need an Adaptation Project for it. If your default values are static, you can do them in Adapt UI as well, but if values are dynamic (ie. depend on certain conditions) then you need to create an Adaptation Project in BAS and add your logic in the controller extension.

I find that if I can do everything in Adap UI then I don't create an Adaptation Project, since I don't need it. But if there is at least one thing that I need Adaptation Project for, then I do everything in the project and not use Adapt UI at all.

Hope this helps.

entry.title: Re: Adding new field(select-option) to VL10 report
entry.content:
I know this is a really old topic, but since I had a similar requirement and difficulties to find a good "How-To" which will not require me to modify SAP standard, I will share a quick guide for anyone who might find himself here in the future.

Prerequisites:

I needed to register following objects:

  • RTR3 TABL SHP_VL10_ITEM (Item-Structure for ALV data) 
  • R3TR TABL /ISDFPS/SHP_VL10_SELECT_OPTION (Needed for the custom SELECT-OPTIONS append) 
  • R3TR FUGR V50R_VIEW (UserExits)
  • R3TR PROG V50R_USEREXIT_TRANSF (Introducing the custom SELECT-OPTIONS to the standard structure) 

I created following data elements:

  • Structure: ZSHP_<CUSTOM_FIELD>_RANGE (Ranges-Table Structure for SELECT-OPTIONS)
  • Tabletype: ZSHP_<CUSTOM_FIELD>_RANGE_T (Ranges-Table with linetype ZSHP_<CUSTOM_FIELD>_RANGE)

The ranges structure should follow this template: 

SIGN Type SIGN CHAR 1 0 prefix
OPTION Type OPTION CHAR 2 0 option for range tables
LOW Type <data_element_required> <corresponding data type> <description>
HIGH Type <data_element_required> <corresponding data type> <description>

I changed following structures: 

  • SHP_VL10_SELECT_OPTIONS (Introduced a new field Z_<CUSTOM_FIELD> TYPE ZSHP_<CUSTOM_FIELD>_RANGE_T for the custom SELECT-OPTIONS)
  • SHP_VL10_ITEM (Appended a new structure e.g. ZNEWDATA with one component ZZ_<CUSTOM_FIELD> TYPE <DATATYPE_OF_CUSTOM_FIELD>)

The first step was to copy the report RV50R10C to a new Z-Report, e.g. ZRV50R10C (including ZRVV50TOP, ZV50RINCL,ZV50RSEL3).

**The following steps will only be relevant if you want to access the custom report with VL10A to VL10I transactions.

Create a Z-Transaction for each VL10-Transaction using SE93 and the copy function. That's VL10X, VL10A, VL10B, VL10C, VL10D, VL10E, VL10F, VL10G, VL10H, VL10I.

Copy the function group V50R_PRE to a custom function group, e.g. Z_VL10 and copy all of the included Function Modules aswell. 

Also copy the report RVV50R10_PRESTEP to a custom one, e.g. ZRVV50R10_PRESTEP. 

In the custom function module, e.g. ZZSHP_VL10_PRESTEP change the if statement: "IF … ZRVV50R10C". 
In SE93 VL10X transaction, change report name to ZRVV50R10_PRESTEP.
In ZRVV50R10_PRESTEP change FM call to "CALL FUNCTION 'ZZSHP_VL10_PRESTEP'"

**The previous steps will only be relevant if you want to access the custom report with VL10A to VL10I transactions.
 
In ZRV50R10C add a new text-symbol containing the text for your custom subscreen tab when VL10 is called. Then add this code: S0S_TABX = TEXT-099.

In ZV50RSEL3 add the tab and the subscreen definition:

SELECTION-SCREEN TAB (30) s0s_tabx
USER-COMMAND s0s_tabx
DEFAULT SCREEN 1080.

....

SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF SCREEN 1080 AS SUBSCREEN.
SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK v50rsel_block_e WITH FRAME.
SELECT-OPTIONS: so_<custom_field> FOR <table>-<field>.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK v50rsel_block_e.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF SCREEN 1080.

Then, in UserExit: V50R_USEREXIT_TRANSF you have to make the custom SELECT-OPTIONS know to the standard SELECT-OPTIONS-Structure: 

cx_select_options-<name custom element from shp_vl10_select_options>[] = <custom_select_options definition name>[].

In the UserExit LV50R_VIEWG03 the values from the custom SELECT-OPTIONS can be checked and data from the ALV output can be excluded:

SELECT SINGLE <field> FROM <table> WHERE <conditions> AND <field> IN @ix_SELECT_OPTIONS-<custom_select_options> INTO @CS_postab-<custom_field>
IF sy-subrc NE 0.
cf_subrc = 1.
ENDIF.

After leaving this User Exit with cf_subrc = 1 it will be CHECKED afterwards and data will not be appended to the ALV output table. The cs_postab field corresponds with the name you have given in your SHP_VL10_ITEM append. 

If you want to have the new field displayed in the ALV directly after running the program, I would recommend to create a default layout with your field included. Maybe you can also use LV50R_VIEWG11 to a certain extend, but be aware, I think some adjustment might be overwritten, since the default user role parameters in the VL10 will be retrieved only after this UserExit and therefore potentially overwrite your custom settings here.

entry.title: SAP Enable Now – Different Workflows for Original and Translated Objects Within the Same Workarea
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm currently working with SAP Enable Now and have encountered an issue related to workflow management within a single workarea.

Here’s the situation:

  • I’ve created a QA workflow that automatically publishes content after a successful quality assurance step.

  • All content is initially created in German.

  • Later, we want to translate the existing content into other languages – especially Simulations, where we plan to use the translation feature and re-recording functionality provided by SAP Enable Now.

For the translation process, we would like to use a separate workflow.

So far, I’ve created two workflows:

  1. One for the initial content creation in German (with automatic publishing).

  2. One for translations (with a different review process).

The problem:
A workarea in Enable Now can only be assigned one workflow. However, we’d like that when an object is duplicated for translation, it would automatically follow the second (translation) workflow without needing to switch workareas manually.

My question:
Is there a way to apply different workflows within the same workarea, depending on the object type, status, or context (e.g. original vs. translation)?
Alternatively, is there a best practice for handling translation processes that require a different workflow setup while staying within the same project or workarea?

Thank you very much in advance for any advice or input!

Best regards,

Janice

SAP Enable Now

entry.title: Re: freight-cost-condition divided per position in outbou...
entry.content:
SAP’s standard header-freight logic always splits the freight (condition type ZFRE) across all line items in each billing document, using the sum of that invoice’s net values as the denominator. On a second invoice for the same order, if ZFRE still exists, the system takes that new invoice’s net‐value sum and redistributes the freight—hence your “10 – 4 – 2 = 4 €” behavior.

To instead have full 10 € split pro-rata only on the first delivery/billing (and zero freight thereafter), you must inject custom logic into the pricing routine for ZFRE. Here’s how:

Option 1: Custom VOFM Calculation Routine

  • In SPRO → Pricing → Pricing Control → Define Condition Types, edit ZFRE, Set Condition Class = B (Header Condition), Under Calculation assign a custom routine (e.g. 900 or ZZ1).
  • Implement your VOFM routine (Transaction V/06, choose type B routine = ZZ1)
  • Rebuild your pricing procedure or run a pricing re‐determination on your first invoice.
  • On the first billing document, SAP will see C_VALUE = 10 and pro-rate it by each item’s net-value. Your delivered 10 + 5 = 15 € → splits into 6.67 €/3.33 €.
  • On subsequent bills, the routine returns C_VALUE = 0, so no freight appears.

Option 2: BAdI-Based Pricing Exit

  • If you cannot use VOFM routines (for example, in a public-cloud extension scenario), leverage a pricing‐exit BAdI instead:
    classic MV45AFZX user‐exit in the pricing program
  • In your method, replicate the above logic by reading the doc number and count existing invoices, if first invoice → set cond amount = 10, else → cond amount = 0.

The pricing program then pro-rata splits the header condition.

entry.title: Re: Sales Order - Return VA01
entry.content:
In Brazilian‐localized SD, the billing‐document header field STCD1 (“Tax Number 1”) is automatically populated from the master data of the partner assigned the “invoice‐issuer” role. In a standard outbound invoice, that’s your sold-to/payer customer (so you see the customer’s CNPJ).

However, in a sales-return credit memo, SAP treats the document more like a vendor invoice to your own company—and the “invoice‐issuer” ends up being the company code’s BP (or the vendor BP behind it). As a result, STCD1 is picked up from your own company code’s CNPJ master parameters rather than the customer’s.

Key Configuration Areas Affecting STCD1

Partner Determination in Billing Type (OBO1 / VOV8) Check which partner function is flagged as invoice‐issuer for credit-memo type ZBDE. If it’s mapped to your company’s BP or vendor BP instead of the customer’s “payer” partner, STCD1 comes from the wrong master.

Copy Control – Sales to Billing (VTFL) Under Billing Type → Header Data → “Tax Number from”, you choose whether STCD1 is copied from the customer (KNA1-STCD1) or from the company code’s global FI parameters. The default for returns is often “own company.”

BP Master & CNPJ Maintenance

  • Customer BP: STCD1 holds the CNPJ entered on the Control Data tab of the customer master.
  • Company Code (Vendor) BP: Its CNPJ lives in FI Global Parameters → Company Code → Additional Details.

How to force the Customer’s CNPJ into STCD1 is by adjusting Partner Determination – In SPRO → Sales & Distribution → Basic Functions → Partner Determination → Assign Partner Functions to Billing – For your return‐billing type ZBDE, ensure the payer or sold-to partner function (the one carrying STCD1) is the customer, not your company code/vendor BP.

Copy Control Settings – Go to SPRO → Sales & Distribution → Billing → Copy Control (Order → Billing) – Select your return billing type → Header Data tab → Field “Tax Number from”: choose Customer Master instead of Company Code.

If none of the above options are not working, then, you need to explore custom validation either via USEREXIT_FILL_VBRK_BTE (in include MV45AFZZ) or the BAdI SD_BILLING_DOCUMENT.

entry.title: AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
The AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite is a Generative AI driven capability available exclusively on SAP Integration Suite. For the first time in SAP CI, leverage SAP AI Core’s GenAI Hub features that allow you to achieve smarter integration solutions for your business.

AICore-GenAIHub variant allows you to connect to orchestration services in SAP AI Core. This service enables the use of various generative AI models with a unified code, configuration, and deployment.

The Custom-OpenAI-REST variant of the AI adapter works with the APIs of OpenAI that allows developers to access and integrate with artificial intelligence models into their applications, enabling tasks like text generation, image creation, and more.

AI Adapter Features

The AI Adapter has the following features:

  • AI Adapter has two variants available: AICore-GenAIHub and Custom-OpenAI-REST.
  • AI Adapter supports OAuth2 Client Credential (User Credentials) and API Key alias (Secure Parameter) authentication methods for the AICore-GenAIHub and Custom-OpenAI-REST variant respectively.
  • AICore-GenAIHub employs harmonized API to allow you to use different foundation models without changing the client code.
  • You can configure orchestration to enable consumption of multiple GenAI models within a single workflow.
  • Custom-OpenAI-REST allows you to access a range of features using APIs like Chat Completions, Platform and Responses.
  • Custom-OpenAI-REST supports Basic configuration type that provides a convenient processing capability for supported versions whereas Advanced enables proficient users to perform calls with greater control while connecting to any API endpoint. 

Example Scenario : Sentiment Analysis on Customer Feedback 

In this blog post, we will demo a scenario to get you started with a basic AI Adapter operation. We query LLM to perform sentiment analysis on user feedback.

 

The following prerequisites are handy while getting started with GenAI Hub

  • To get started with Gen AI Hub, see Getting Started with GenAIHub.
  • To consume GenAI models using Orchestration, see AI Core Orchestration Consumption.

Prepare User feedback using Content Modifier

One of the first tasks we do after creating a new integration flow is to prepare contrasting user feedback to be analyzed. As you can notice, one of them speaks highly of the blog (we assume this to be a product) and other feedback is quite the opposite.

Connect to GenAI Hub using the AI Adapter

The Connection tab contains connection and authentication parameters to connect to AICore-GenAIHub.

 

Parameter

Description

Address

Specify the GenAIHub address.

Example: https://api.ai.{tenant_name}.{datacenter}.ml.hana.ondemand.com.

OAuth2 Client Credentials

Specify the name of the OAuth2 Client Credentials security artifact.

Reuse Connection

Enable to reuse the connection.

Connection Timeout(in ms)

Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for the connection to be established.

Response Timeout(in ms)

Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for a response message.

Prompt an LLM using AI Adapter

This example demonstrates how to prompt a large language model (LLM) to perform sentiment analysis on for user feedback text. The model is instructed to analyze the sentiment of the review and respond with just one word—either “positive” or “negative.” Triple backticks are used to clearly highlight the review text, ensuring there's no ambiguity about what should be analyzed. The structure is intended to produce straightforward and concise sentiment assessments.

Parameter

Description

Operation

Select the operation from the dropdown.

Orchestration Deployment ID

Specify the Deployment ID for this Orchestration.

AI Resource Group

Specify the AI Resource Group configured for the specific orchestration deployment.

Request Payload Source

 

Select an option to specify the source for request payload:

  • Exchange Body allows you to specify required structure and values. 
  • UI Configurable provides user friendly fields to create the payload automatically.

 

Model

Select the required AI model for your operation.

 

Role

Specify the role to be assumed:

  • assistant
  • system
  • user

Input

Specify the content containing the instruction to be carried out.

Run and Verify Output

After saving the above configuration, deploy the flow and verify that the sentiment has been correctly analyzed.

You should be able to see some of them as shown below:

 

Quick Links

For detailed information about AI configuration, see AI Adapter and AI Adapter Guide.

Note: The AI adapter is available as part of your SAP Integration Suite license.

entry.title: SMB Adapter Feature: On-Premise Connectivity via SAP Cloud Connector
entry.content:
The Microsoft SMB (Server Message Block) Adapter now supports on-premise connectivity via the SAP Cloud Connector. SAP Integration Suite supports this using the proxy type ‘On-Premise’.

You can securely integrate your SAP cloud applications with your on-premise SMB server. It offers reliable authentication and authorization mechanisms to ensure that only authorized users and systems can access on-premises resources.

Following the July What's New release announcement, SMB Adapter for SAP Integration Suite ships with this Cloud Connector capability.

To achieve this setup, you need to perform the following steps:

  1. Configure a new Cloud to On-Premise system mapping in your Cloud Connector.
  2. Configure the SMB Adapter to Create, Read, and Write on your On-Premise File Server.

Configure Cloud to On-Premise system mapping in your Cloud Connector

  1. Navigate to your Cloud connector login page and enter your credentials.
  2. Now, you must define a subaccount for Cloud Connector. Select Define Subaccount, enter the necessary details, and click Save.
  3. Choose the Cloud To On-Premises option from the menu and click
  4. Select Back-end Type as Non-SAP System and click Next.
  5. Select Protocol as TCP and click Next.
  6. Here you can specify your On-Premise SMB server & port that needs to be set up for connectivity. Populate Internal Host and Port or Port Range to proceed.
  7. Specify the Virtual Host and Virtual Port that is exposed for connectivity with the SMB Adapter.
  8. Enter the Description as required and click Next.
  9. Verify the details and click Finish.
    (Note: Ensure to enable the Check Internal Host).
  10. Now, you can view your details in your Cloud To On-Premise.
    (Note: Once deployed, Check Result should be Reachable).

Configure SMB Adapter to connect to SMB File Share

SMB adapter simplifies integration with on-premise file systems, making it easier to read, write, and manage files across network shares. In our scenario, we will demo creation of a directory and file, followed by subsequent read and write operations on the same file.

Configure Connection tab for SMB Adapter

The SMB receiver adapter supports basic authentication, enabling users to configure and use the adapter with ease.

To connect to the SMB server, you need to specify the Host and port of SMB, select the Proxy type as On-Premise, and specify the location ID to identify the location of a Cloud Connector instance for a specific subaccount, which is used as routing information.

Now, select the Version and Drive on which you need to perform the operation and specify the Credentials stored in the SAP Security materials. For more information, refer image below.

Create, Read and Write using SMB Server

The SMB Adapter supports all CRUD operations. We will first create a directory and a file to read data from the file. Firstly, you need to perform the Create Directory operation in the SMB local server using the SMB receiver adapter.


Response in Local SMB Drive

Once the directory is successfully created, the next step is to create a file within that directory. This file will serve as the container for your data. You should then write or insert all the required records into this file using a content modifier, ensuring the content is structured and stored correctly for further processing or retrieval.

Response in Local SMB Drive

After the file has been created, you can use the Read File operation provided by the SMB adapter to access and retrieve the data from it in the future.

Response

Conclusion:

SMB adapter allows users to connect to an On-Premise server using SAP Cloud Connector.

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Business Partner Toolset (BDT) at Business Partner
entry.content:
Hi David,

please keep in mind that you are working on different data structure levels:
Supplier Master (General Section)
Vendor master record purchasing organization data
Vendor Master Record: Purchasing Data (Supplier Subrange)

It is only possible to combine data on the same level. Background is the mandatory information of each level. e.g. Purch.Org. or Suppl.Subrange.
If you do so, it will work.

Best Regards
Andi

entry.title: New integration packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration
entry.content:
I would like to share with you an important change for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration that we did based on feedback we received from customers running the Pipeline. As a result, new integration packages for supporting the Pipeline for Cloud Integration has been recently shipped on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Those packages replace the so far provided package Process Integration Pipeline - Generic Integration Flows & Templates which will be deprecated soon.

To be more flexible in setting up your different pipelines, different sender-specific IDoc and XI inbound flows, and receiver-specific outbound flows if required, we decided to split up the Process Integration Pipeline - Generic Integration Flows & Templates into four packages. For the same reason, the script collection has been replaced by local scripts.

Customers like to run different pipelines, e.g., for distributing their critical and non-critical scenarios across different pipelines, or setting up different pipelines in a shared tenant environment. Also, it makes sense to define an own IDoc or XI inbound flow for each sender system to be able for instance to define a sender-specific user role or to stop incoming messages for a specific sender system. For those uses cases, so far you had to copy the package with the complete number of integration flows from the Discovery to the Design adding a suffix. This ensured that the copied packages were not cut off from future updates. However, downside was that this resulted in a large number of stale artifacts, so integration flows which were not used at all.

With the new package setup, we now better support those use cases without creating all those stale integration artifacts. The approach is still to copy a new package from the Discovery, but depending on the use case, you would only copy the integration flows which are required for the respective use case.

You can now find the generic integration flows and a set of templates for the scenario-specific integration flows and custom exits spread across the following integration packages:

  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Inbound: Contains the generic IDoc and XI inbound flows.
  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Pipelines: Contains the main generic pipeline steps.
  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound: Contains the generic outbound processing flow.
  • Cloud Integration Pipeline - Templates: Contains all templates for the scenario-specific flows and custom extensions.

Note: As said, the so far provided integration package will be deprecated soon. All new feature increments will only be shipped with the new integration packages. So, If you have used the previously provided package, you need to switch to the new packages. To do so, proceed as follows:

  • Undeploy all generic flows from the soon to be deprecated package.
  • Configure and deploy the required generic flows provided by the new Cloud Integration Pipeline packages. You can either deploy all generic flows or just the ones that you need depending on which pipeline you use, see below.
  • If you have used scripts from the script collection in your scenario-specific flows, replace the scripts with local scripts. You find the local scripts in either the generic flows or the new templates. As long as you haven't replaced all scripts, recommendation is to still run the script collection. Once done, you can then also undeploy the script collection.

Note: In the newly shipped Cloud Integration packages, the name and IDs of the integration flows have version v2 added. It's important that the old integration flows and the new integration flows must not be deployed together because they compete on reading from the same JMS queues.

The templates package doesn't contain any artifact which needs to be deployed nor does it need to be transported to the production tenant. It only contains templates that you can copy to create your scenario-specific flows and custom flows. For this reason, we kept those integration flows in a separate package.

For setting up the integrated messaging runtime for asynchronous communication (recommended option for asynchronous communication), you need to deploy the following generic integration flows:

  • (Optionally, if you like to use a single entry point for IDoc messages) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for Idoc
  • (Optionally, if you like to use a single entry point for XI messages) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for XI
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step02 - Integrated Messaging Runtime Async
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step06 - Outbound Processing

For setting up the integrated messaging runtime for synchronous content-based-router scenarios, you need to deploy the following generic integration flows:

  • (Optionally) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for XI
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step02 - Integrated Messaging Runtime Sync

For setting up the fully decoupled pipeline for asynchronous communication, you need to deploy the following integration flows:

  • (Optionally) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for Idoc
  • (Optionally) Pipeline v2 Generic Step01 - Inbound Processing for XI
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step02 - Inbound Processing
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step04 - Receiver Determination
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step05 - Interface Determination
  • Pipeline v2 Generic Step06 - Outbound Processing

All integration flows within the new Cloud Integration packages have been copied from the old package. Besides this, some new features have been added which I will soon describe in a bit more detail in a separate blog post. You also find this information in the change logs of the packages. Upfront, here some of the new features that we have shipped with the new packages:

  • For IDoc inbound scenarios where you exchange IDoc bulk messages, you have the option to keep the bulk, i.e., not to split the bulk message into individual messages.
  • You can now call a custom exit integration flow for custom pre-processing without the need to alter the standard generic flows of the pipeline. This can be configured globally or scenario-specific. Potential use cases could be to implement additional external or internal logging capabilities or to stop certain messages from sending to the receiver systems based on some conditions, e.g. maintained in the Partner Directory.
  • A new template has been added that allows you to implement custom receiver and interface determination by maintaining exchange properties. A similar approach is applied in the SAP Process Orchestration to Cloud Integration migration tool when selecting the standard migration approach for the Recipient List and Content-Based-Router patterns.
  • A new template has been added for an option to implement custom receiver determination based on a message mapping and by maintaining exchange properties for the interface determination. A similar approach is applied in the SAP Process Orchestration to Cloud Integration migration tool when selecting the Pipeline migration approach.
  • For the Outbound Processing templates, an option to call custom post-processing has been added.
  • We fixed an issue in the duplication check caused by a wrong usage of the escalation end event for the IDoc and XI inbound processing flow.

We are currently updating the standard documentation, so stay tuned.

entry.title: Re: Automatic Stock Transfer Requisition Based on ATP Che...
entry.content:
To fulfill customer demand in plant 1010 by tapping stock in plants 1710 and 3310—and have the system automatically generate the intercompany requisitions—you need two pillars in place:

  • Define 1710/3310 as valid supply sources for material TG00
  • Enable an ATP check that searches alternative plants at sales-order entry

Below is a step-by-step blueprint.

1. Define Supplying Plants for TG00

  • In Manage Material Master (Fiori) or MM02, open TG00 → MRP 2 view.
  • Set Special Procurement = 40 (Stock Transfer).
  • This flags the material as procured via inter-plant stock transfer rather than local production or external purchase.


Use a combination of source list entries and intercompany PIRs so MRP (and later ATP) knows where to pull from:

Source List (Fiori “Manage Source Lists” or ME01)

  • Create two entries for material TG00 in plant 1010: one pointing to supply plant 1710, one to 3310.
  • Set the indicator “Stock Transfer” and validity dates.

Intercompany Purchasing Info Record (Fiori “Manage Purchasing Info Records” or ME11)

  • Create PIRs for TG00 with vendor = logical supplier 1710, and another for 3310.
  • Use Info-Record Type = “Intercompany Stock Transfer”.


2. Enable ATP Check Across Multiple Plants

Ensure the advanced ATP scope item is active in your public-cloud system (no self-service UI; raise an SAP Service Request if needed). This unlocks the multi-plant search and supply-area features of SAP S/4HANA’s aATP engine.

In Manage Your Solution → Supply Chain → Advanced ATP → Scope of Check (SSCUI ID 103902):

  • Under Stocks, enable “Check alternative plants”.
  • Under Future Supplies, include planned orders/PRs if needed and save.

This instructs the ATP engine to, at the confirmed delivery date, look beyond 1010 into the source-list plants.


In Manage Your Solution → Sales → Schedule Line → Assign Schedule Line Categories:

  • For your Sales Order type → Item Category → Schedule-Line Category mapping, pick an ATP profile that references the above scope-of-check and save.

Now, during sales-order entry, SAP will run the aATP check and propose supply from 1710/3310 to fulfill the requested delivery.


3. Automate Stock-Transfer Requisition Creation

Once ATP confirms supply from an external plant, you can have the system create the intercompany stock-transfer request (PR or STO) immediately:

  • Activate scope item 5HP – Advanced Intercompany Stock Transfer.
  • In Purchase Requisition Management, map the PR type for “Stock Transfer” to trigger an intercompany STO (or direct PO) via the Fiori “Manage Purchase Requisition Types” app.
  • Ensure workflow for auto-approval or orchestration to PI/CPI for intercompany PO creation.

With 5HP active, every sales-order line confirmed against an external plant spawns the downstream procurement document without manual intervention.


Below is the Configuration & Process Checklist

entry.title: Review Booklet (Template) In Margin Analysis For Company Profitability Reporting
entry.content:
Motivation

 In SAP Cloud ERP 2508, SAP delivered a new review booklet (template) in Margin Analysis for Company Profitability reporting, showing a 3-level Contribution Margin for a Company Code.

In this article I will   explain the purpose of the Company Profitability Review Booklet (Template) app, how the data for the margin levels is selected, and how you can use the template out of the box.

What Can the Company Profitability Review Booklet (Template) App Do For You?

The booklet provides Management Accounting insights, which are not yet available on a structured and aggregated level.

It allows a multi-dimensional analysis of contribution margins on 3 levels using Margin Analysis relevant attributes.

 The booklet technology offers highly adaptable financial reporting based on actual postings (ACODCA). This ensures that users have access to precise and detailed information, enhancing decision-making processes.

With advanced formatting options, users can customize reports to suit their needs. The technology also supports downloading and collaboration features, making it easier for teams to work together seamlessly.

As technology advances, so does the booklet. It incorporates AI features, ensuring that users benefit from the latest innovations in financial reporting.

The booklet has standard extensibility functionality to enable adoptability via key user apps.

Contribution Margin Measure Structure And The Reason It Is Called A Template

SAP uses the Functional Areas from Best Practice Content, so the selection needs to be adjusted by customers.

That is why it is called a Template.

If you use the SAP delivered Function Areas (YB18 to YB50) in your cost objects, you can use the Company Profitability Review Booklet (Template) app out of the box.

If not, you need to adjust the selection in the CDS Analytical Query using Key User tools.

I will explain this in another blog.

Key Capabilities

The new review booklet is delivered with SAP Cloud ERP 2508.

It is based on SAP Best Practices Contribution Margin Financial Statement Version (FSV) YPS2 and its semantic tags.

It shows 3 levels of Contribution Margin:
I           Revenues / Related variable costs
II          / Related fixed costs, warranties and variances
III         / Company periodic costs

The booklet is cross-industry, so it can read different account assignments:

  • Market Segments (EO) for Sales Order etc.
  • Projects (PR), with all attributes
  • Service Contracts/Orders (SC, SV), with all attributes
  • Cost Centers (KS, KL) and Orders (OR) for non-allocated costs

With Universal Journal integration we can read costs directly from those cost objects including the attributed Margin Analysis dimensions. There is no need to settle or allocate costs to Market Segments.

Figure 1: Year-to-date comparison of 3-level contribution margin for a company code

 The hierarchical structure of the measures is hard coded in the underlying CDS Analytical Query.

Each measure has semantic tags assigned from FSV YPS2, so GL Account assignments can be adjusted in configuration. You can use your own FSV, but you must use the same semantic tags.

Fixed/variable costs are read from the ACDOCA amount fields.

 you also need to select additional ACDOCA dimensions for the following measures to get correct amounts:

  • Functional Area (to distinguish between COGS and periodic costs)
  • Billable Control (remove warranty costs)
  • Subledger Line Item Type (to distinguish production variances)

Figure 2: Hierarchical measure structure for the 3-level contribution margin

 Data Selection In Detail

The system reads actual revenue and cost in Company Code currency from ACDOCA using the cube I_GLAcctLineItemSemTagGLAcct with Semantic Tags

 You can access all Margin Analysis data from a set of Cost Objects. Select the Account Assignment Type as follows:

  • EO (Market Segment)
  • PR (Project)
  • SV (Service Order Item)
  • SC (Service Contract)
  • OR (Order)
  • KS (Cost Center)
  • VB (Sales Document Item)
  • KL (Cost Center and Activity)

 You need to distinguish the measures between Read (RKF) and Calculated (Calc) figures.

Calculated figures are based on Read Key Figures and just have a calculation formula without selection criteria.

The Read Key Figures always use a Semantic Tag in the selection.

Please refer to the full list, to get an overview.

Figure 3: List of calculated and read key figures with selection criteria

The reason why additional selection on some figures is required is because SAP uses the Semantic Tag PL_RESULT on several RKFs. PL_RESULT contains all G/L Accounts maintained in the financial statement version.

To ensure we do not count costs on the same account in several key figures, we need to restrict further.

Periodic Costs

Let’s have a look at the periodic costs first. We want to distinguish periodic costs into the following:

  • Marketing
  • Sales
  • Administration
  • Research & Development

 There are 4 different measures using the Semantic Tag PL_RESULT.

We added the delivered Best Practices FSV YPS2 some more Primary Cost G/L Accounts with SAP Cloud ERP 2508 under a new node called Common Operational Cost Gls (Node ID 74). Please check if you need additional G/L Accounts and add them. If you were a customer before SAP Cloud ERP 2508, you will need to add this node and all G/L Accounts you want to see costs under PL_RESULT.

 The PL_RESULT tag is used here (all costs) to ensure we also see costs in the report that are not being allocated to Margin Analysis using Universal Allocation or Settlement. Primary costs remain on Cost Centers or WBS Element. We could restrict via a Semantic Tag to the corresponding allocation or settlement G/L accounts, if settlement and allocation were done from all object using the secondary G/L Accounts, but this is rarely the case.

 To ensure we have different costs summed on the 4 measures, we use the Functional Areas from Best Practices:

  • YB35: Marketing
  • YB30: Sales
  • YB40: Administration
  • YB50: Research & Development

The Functional Area is always filled in ACDOCA and derived from the Cost Object (Cost Center, WBS Element) on which the periodic costs are posted.

Of course, we continue to display periodic costs allocated or settled to Market Segments. Users can then also drill down into the used dimensions like Product or Customer Group. The system credits allocated costs to the cost center without the Market Segment dimension. This ensures that costs do not appear twice in the total.

 

Figure 4: Example for allocated and non-allocated periodic costs by G/L account in the review booklet

 

Price Differences (Or Production Variances)

A similar case is Price Difference or Production Variance, which can occur on Production Orders and are posted to Market Segment dimensions of a Production Order, once it is completed.

We want to distinguish variance into the following:

  • Input Price
  • Input Quantity
  • Resource Usage
  • Lot Size
  • Output Price
  • Input Remaining

So, we have different Read Key Figures all with Semantic Tag PL_RESULT, since different variance can occur on the same G/L Account.

Therefore, we use the Sub-ledger Line Item Type to further restrict the different amounts.

It is filled by production variance calculation in ACDOCA when posted to Market Segments.

Warranty Costs

We also want to show warranty costs as a measure using Semantic Tag PL_RESULT, since all kinds of G/L Account can carry warranty cost.

For all warranty costs, the Billable Control (or Accounting Indicator ACDOCA-BEMOT) is filled to configurable values like “Non-Billable Demand” or “Goodwill”. This allows us to read with Billable Control not initial.

All Other Costs Of Good Sold

For all other COGS measures in our structure, we make use of the fix and variable separation in ACDOCA and have different sematic tags.

In addition, we use the Best Practice Functional Areas

  • YB18: Cost of Goods Sold
  • YB25: Consulting/Services

 To ensure we only count product and service-related costs in the Contribution Margin I and II we also restrict to Billable Control/Accounting Indicator is initial to not include warranty costs.

 Revenues And Sales Deductions

For revenue and sales deduction figures, it is enough to read the semantic tags and assigned G/L Accounts without the Functional Area.

Navigation to Line-Item Reporting

To verify the aggregated data, users can navigate to the line-item report for Margin Analysis. They can then filter using the criteria for each measure. Semantic tags are resolved into G/L Account through navigation.

Other filters are kept as defined.

Figure 5: Navigation to Display Line Items – Margin Analysis to  measure warranty costs

Figure 6: Filters in Display Line Items – Margin Analysis to measure warranty costs

The sum in the line-item report should fit the figure in the booklet, with the following limitations:

  • For Fixed/Variable Cost measures, you can verify only the Fixed Amount and need to calculate the Variable as Total minus Fixed.  This is available only for Group Currency.
  • If the booklet includes additional page filters for fields which are not available as filters in the line-item report (e.g. for fiscal quarter), the sum might not match.

Conclusion And Outlook

You now understand the purpose and logic of the booklet and know when you need to adopt.

We would highly appreciate your feedback on this article.

In future we plan to add additional features to the booklet, e.g.

  • Display of amounts in Group Currency
  • Selection and comparison of several Company Codes
  • Commenting
  • Business Insights powered by AI

entry.title: Re: Consolidated subcontracting PR for multiple productio...
entry.content:
By design, SAP’s operation-subcontracting creates one purchase requisition (PR) per production order when you release or confirm the external operation. There is no standard toggle to “group” PRs across independent orders—each order is treated separately. However, you have two practical routes to meet your requirement of a single, consolidated PR:

SAP delivers a Combined Production Order function (often known as DIMP or via tcode MILL_OC) that lets you merge several orders—provided they share the same material, BOM, routing and external‐operation control key—into a single “combined” order. When you release that combined order, SAP will generate one subcontracting PR for the external operation covering the total quantity of all original orders.

How to set it up:

  • Enable the Industry Solution “Combined Production Order Processing” in SFW5 (or request activation from SAP for your private-edition tenant).
  • In SPRO → Production → Shop Floor Control → Master Data → Administer Selection Profile for Combination, create a profile (e.g. Z_COMB) that allows the orders you want to combine.
  • Use tcode MILL_OC (or the Fiori app Combine Production Orders if delivered) to:  Select Plant, Profile Z_COMB and the orders to merge.   Execute to create Combined Order C100123 (for example)
  • Release Combined Order C100123 → one PR is generated for the external operation.
  • Perform confirmations, GR, and settlement on either the combined order or back‐distribute to originals as needed.

Benefits

  • Zero custom code
  • Fully supported by SAP
  • Single PR covers all quantities

Limitation

  • Only works when orders share identical BOM/routing for the external op

If you cannot—or do not want to—combine orders, you can intercept PR creation and funnel all requests into a single, pre‐existing PR. This will require a small ABAP enhancement:

User‐Exit / BAdI Spot

Use the classic MM06E user‐exit EXIT_SAPMM06E_025 (include LMEPOA01) or the class‐based BAdI ME_PROCESS_REQUISITION (Enhancement Spot ME_REQUISITION_REDIST) that fires when a subcontracting PR is generated.

Logic Sketch

  • On first PR creation for Vendor V in your time window, let SAP create PR “Z000123.”
  • Store Z000123 in a Z-table keyed by Vendor + External Op + Date
  • On subsequent triggers for the same Vendor/Op within that window, Suppress the auto‐creation of a new PR • Append the new line item(s) to PR “Z000123” (use BAPI_PR_CREATE or BAPI_REQUISITION_CHANGE). Update the production-order external‐operation tab to reference Z000123.

The result would be all your operation-subcontract quantities flow into one PR instead of many.

Trade-Offs

  • Requires ABAP development and thorough testing
  • Must handle exception cases (e.g. mixed materials, different delivery dates)
  • Ongoing maintenance with upgrades

If the question is which approach to choose?,

  • If your orders are homogeneous (same material, same routing), Combined Order is the simplest, zero-code, fully supported SAP solution.
  • If you need to keep orders separate but still “pool” PRs, the custom‐enhancement route gives you full control—at the expense of implementation effort.

entry.title: Navigating Mime Type Mismatches in SAP Commerce Cloud
entry.content:
Overview

Are you working with SAP Commerce Cloud and encountering image conversion issues where the mime type doesn't match the format you’ve defined? This mismatch can lead to conversion failures, accompanied by error messages about improper image headers. In this post, we'll guide you through understanding this issue, the steps to reproduce it, and how to resolve it effectively.

What's Happening?

If you're noticing that converted images don’t reflect the mime type you've set, you're not alone. When converting media, you might see error messages like:

convert: improper image header `/tmp/src***' @ error/png.c/ReadPNGImage/3964. convert: no images defined `/tmp/target*** @ error/convert.c/ConvertImageCommand/3354.

This problem typically arises in SAP Commerce Cloud versions 2211.31 to 2211.38.

How to Identify the Issue

Here’s a simple walkthrough to help you identify when and why this issue occurs:

  1. Setting Up Media Formats:

    • Define a conversion media format (let's call it MF1) and specify its mime type as image/png.
    • Set up another media format, MF2.

  2. Configuring Conversion Parameters:

    • In MF2's editor, set the input format to MF1 under the conversion section and save your settings.

  3. Creating a Conversion Group:

    • Establish a conversion group (CG1) and add MF1 and MF2 to its supported formats.

  4. Uploading Media Files:

    • Upload a JPEG file to a new media item, img1.

  5. Setting Up a Media Container:

    • Create a media container (MC1) and assign the conversion group CG1 to it. Include img1 in your media content and save changes.

  6. Triggering Conversion:

    • Make a quick switch of the selected media container away from MC1 and back to enable the Convert Missing Medias button. Click this button to start conversion.
    • You might find that only img1_MF1 media is produced with the mime type shown as image/jpeg instead of image/png, causing conversion errors due to this mismatch.

Why Does This Happen?

The issue is caused by a recent Azure SDK library upgrade. This update changed how mime types are calculated during conversion, affecting how InputStream implementations determine the number of bytes in the conversion process.

How Can You Fix It?

A permanent solution is available from SAP Commerce Cloud version 2211.39, which resolves these conversion conflicts. We recommend upgrading to this version to eliminate these issues.

What If Upgrade Isn’t Possible?

If upgrading right away isn’t feasible for you, consider this workaround:

Remove the specified mime type from the media format used as input, and instead apply it to your target media formats.

This approach helps maintain consistent conversions by adjusting settings to align with current system capabilities, ensuring your media operations continue seamlessly.

Conclusion

Effectively managing mime types in SAP Commerce Cloud is crucial for smooth media conversions. By leveraging these solutions, you can avoid conversion issues and maintain your project workflow.
For more guidance or assistance, feel free to reach out to SAP Support – we're here to help ensure your success with SAP Commerce Cloud!

entry.title: Re: 2025 Q3 SAP Analytics Cloud compass Highlights
entry.content:
Hi @ThanhHieuNguyen ,

Great to read that you are trying compass out! Let me know how you find it!

To your question:

As Monte Carlo Simulations are stochastic in nature, many different combinations could have yielded the same result of 9M. An example of this is also illustrated in my introduction blog to Monte Carlo Simulation - if throwing three dice, different combinations could yield the sum 11. Hence there is no one single combination which could be determined as the "best" solution. Hence the purpose of using Monte Carlo Simulation is not to derive the absolute optimal combination of how to plan, but to explore the risk context involved when your drivers are fluctuating (e.g. tariffs, market prices, attritions, volume etc.). It is especially helpful in situations such as when you are anticipating fluctuating drivers and want to do a robust test of your budget/planning (what is the worst case? what is the most we can achieve?), or when you want to understand the risk context (aggressive? realistic?) of your top-down target setting.

But I understand your desire, and it is a valid one. We are looking into the topic of optimization for the future where planning could be assisted with more prescriptive analysis. For this the timeline is currently open, but it is a topic on our radar. 

Cheers!
Chen Nee

entry.title: How to change existing hierarchy in PRODHS fields according to SAP note 1070939 ?
entry.content:
Hi everyone

We modified structure PRODHS over a decade ago, and this how it looks like today:

component | type
ZZPRODH1 | PRODH1
ZZPRODH2 | PRODH2
ZZPRODH3 | PRODH3
ZZPRODH4 | PRODH4
ZZPRODH5 | PRODH5
ZZPRODH6 | PRODH6

Recently, we've stumbled upon SAP Note 1070939 - Consulting: Changing the product hierarchy structure PRODHS - SAP for Me , where the recommendation is to name the first 3 components without ZZ prefix (so leaving the name to the names delivered by SAP), and only to add ZZ prefix for additional fields. We modified the fields years and years before the note was published.

In our S/4 system one SAP ABAP class couldn't be activated, because the testclass of this ABAP class expected the PRODH fields 1-3 to exist in PRODS structure. This is the only issue we've identified so far, everything else seems to work despite difference to recommendation of note 1070939.

 

We can't just rename the PRODHS structure components, because we have dozens of generated SD condition tables (Axxx) where the first three PRODHS fields with ZZ prefix are used. 

Has anybody (had) the same challgenge? Did you solve it? Did you leave it? Did you experience anything not to work?

Thanks!

entry.title: Re: Resizing 2D barcodes in Adobe forms
entry.content:
Great! Please also check SAP Note https://me.sap.com/notes/2371197/E

One hint, if your barcode gets completely black, you have set the moduleWidth too high. It does not translate 1:1 to mm oder in.

Example: if your barcode 39 is supposed to be 50mm width, the moduleWidth should be set to ="0.300mm". You need to play around with it a little bit.

entry.title: Re: Check Field and Value Check foreign key table (depend...
entry.content:
Hello @nasuke232 

Great news! Your approach to validating foreign keys in ABAP is correct. Since SAP doesn’t enforce referential integrity on custom Z-tables, you’re on the correct track.

Just make sure, check all parts of the composite key,such as MANDT, RBUKRS, BELNR, and DOCLN, not just a single field. When you write your WHERE clause, include all key fields connected with AND, then run your SELECT SINGLE check.

With this, your validation will stay accurate and help you avoid any tricky mismatches.

Let me know if you need further assistance

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: VA01/VA02 Fiori App (Webgui) - Empty space between He...
entry.content: That blank band between the VA01/VA02 header area and the Items table is not a “bug” but by‐design in the Web GUI-in-FLP shell. SAP reserves that strip for the web-GUI controls (toolbar buttons, filter bar, personal variant buttons, etc.), and it always appears—even if you never use those controls. In the classic SAP GUI for Windows you don’t see it because the native GUI merges everything seamlessly, but the HTML GUI running inside the Fiori Shell must carve out that reserved area. At this time there is no SAP Note or SPRO switch to remove it.

entry.title: Re: ASSET - Error AIST 009
entry.content:
Error AIST009 is raised because, at the point you change the cost center, SAP’s Asset Accounting sees two different profit centers coming from two “account assignment objects” (e.g. Cost Center vs. Investment/Internal Order) and cannot decide which one to use. You attempted SAP Note 3399016 (which deals with company‐status checks), but this message is not controlled by company‐status logic—it’s driven by the Additional Account Assignment Objects customizing in Asset Accounting.

The root cause of conflicting Profit‐Center derivation is because, when you maintain both

  • a cost center (in the time‐dependent tab), and
  • an investment/internal order (in the origin tab),

SAP derives a profit center from each. If those two profit centers differ—​for example 01ADMIN vs. 06PRODUT—​the system throws AIST009 because the profit‐center field must be unique.

In two ways, this can be resolved

You must guarantee that only one profit center source supplies the field (or that both sources derive the same profit center).

In SPRO navigate to Financial Accounting (New) → Asset Accounting → Integration with the New General Ledger Accounting → Additional Account Assignment Objects.

Under Activate Account Assignment Objects, either

  • Deactivate the object you don’t want to derive profit center from (for example the Investment/Internal Order),
  • Or change its priority so the cost‐center object is read first (and if it supplies a PC, the other object is ignored).

Under Specify Account Assignment Types for Account Assignment Objects, set the object you suppress to Not Used (so it never feeds into profit‐center derivation).
Save and transport your changes. Now only the cost center’s profit center is picked, eliminating the conflict.

If both account‐assignment objects must remain active for your business:

Ensure the Internal/Investment Order carries the same profit center as your cost centers.
Update each order (transaction KO02/CJ20N or via mass‐change) so its header profit center matches the cost‐center’s PC.

When both sources agree, AIST009 will no longer trigger.

entry.title: Gateway: "400, Bad request" by raising business exception
entry.content:
In a SAP Gateway Project (SEGW) I am raising a business exception in a *_DELETE_ENTITY method on backend side as:

METHOD xy_delete_entity.
"...
DATA(lo_msg_cont) = me->/iwbep/if_mgw_conv_srv_runtime~get_message_container( ).
lo_msg_cont->reset( ).
lo_msg_cont->add_message(
            iv_msg_type               = 'E'                 " Message Type
            iv_msg_id                 = '42'
            iv_msg_number             = '785' "URL: &1                 " Message Number
            iv_msg_v1                 = CONV #( lv_uri )                 " Message Variable

        DATA(lv_http_status_code) = '200'. "or '400'

entry.title: Re: EWM Inbound/outbound Delivery custom field at item level(/SCWM/PRDI , /SCWM/PRDO )
entry.content:
I have implemented the method /SCWM/IF_EX_DLV_VAL_VALIDATE~CHECK_ITEM to check custo field on item.

 

You also need to access data from DOCID and ITEMID (only 2 parameters)  thanks to the class /scwm/cl_dlv_management_prd and method get_fd_prd_items

Source ABAP CODE 

 DATA:   ls_keys  TYPE /scwm/dlv_detval_key_str,
      lt_items TYPE /scwm/dlv_item_out_prd_tab.

    DATA :
      lo_msg       TYPE REF TO /scwm/cl_dm_message_no,
      lo_dlv_query TYPE REF TO /scwm/cl_dlv_management_prd,
      lo_sp        TYPE REF TO /scdl/cl_sp,
      lo_msg_d     TYPE REF TO /scdl/cl_sp_message_box.


* Only for PDI
    CHECK iv_doccat = wmegc_doccat_pdi.

* Get info from screen
    lo_dlv_query = /scwm/cl_dlv_management_prd=>get_instance( ).
    lo_sp = lo_dlv_query->get_service_provider( wmegc_doccat_pdi ).

    LOOP AT it_keys INTO ls_keys.

* Read info for all items of a delivery
      CALL METHOD lo_dlv_query->get_fd_prd_items
        EXPORTING
          iv_doccat  = iv_doccat
          iv_docid   = ls_keys-docid
          iv_itemid  = ls_keys-itemid
        IMPORTING
          et_items   = lt_items
          eo_message = lo_msg.

* For the current item
      LOOP AT lt_items INTO DATA(ls_items) WHERE itemid = ls_keys-itemid.

* Access to your field in ls_items-xxxx 

ENDLOOP.

entry.title: Re: VA01/VA02 Fiori App (Webgui) - Empty space between He...
entry.content:
Something that is usually unknown by many Basis professionals is the need to always update something called Unified Rendering (UR).

2500800 - Cumulative patches for Unified Rendering (UR-c2 and Lightspeed) - SAP for Me

SAP GUI and Web Dynpro apps have many weird issues like the one described that can be fixed by updating the patch of the UR. They topic is so big they have many central notes for different areas.

2504011 - SAP GUI for HTML: Unified Rendering Update - Instructions and Forecasts - SAP for Me

2090746 - WD ABAP: Unified Rendering Update with TCI - Instructions and Related SAP Notes - SAP for Me

2503680 - WD JAVA & Portal: Unified Rendering Update - Instructions And Related Notes. - SAP for Me

2408180 - UI theme designer on ABAP: Latest Unified Rendering and Base Themes - SAP for Me

Those are central notes where you can find which patch is recommended for you depending on your version.

Even if you S/4HANA has just been upgraded, do not expect the UR is already up to date. Actually it's likely the other way around - those issues usually happen just after an S/4HANA upgrade.

So talk with your system admins / Basis if you are not one. Send them those SAP notes. This is an important matter and impact many other apps.

If the patch is already up to date, of course you can support a case to SAP.

I am using S/4HANA 2023 with UR up to date and I do not see such huge empty space.

entry.title: Re: Connecting a decentralized EWM to a non SAP ERP
entry.content:
When a decentralized EWM tries to post a Goods Receipt back to your back-end ERP, it needs a defined RFC destination and logical‐system entry for that ERP system. If either is missing, you’ll see the error

“The specified R/3 system has not been maintained in the system.”

Below is a step-by-step checklist to fix the error and pointers to the standard SAP documentation for integrating decentralized EWM with a non-SAP ERP.


1. Maintain the ERP Logical System in EWM

In your EWM (S/4) client you must tell EWM what name to use when calling your ERP:

  • Open Manage Your Solution → Implementation Guide.
  • Navigate to Extended Warehouse Management → Interfaces → EWM Decentralized → Define Logical Systems
  • Create an entry for your non-SAP ERP logical system (e.g. NSAPCLNT100).
  • Save and transport.

This step ensures that whenever EWM generates a qRFC or IDoc call, it has a target logical‐system mapping.


2. Configure RFC Destinations for Method Calls

EWM uses RFCs to invoke BAPIs or report functions in the back-end. You must map each integration scenario to a working RFC:

  • In the same IMG area, go to Extended Warehouse Management → Cross-Process Settings → Backend Communication → Define RFC Destinations for Method Calls
  • For each interface (Inbound Delivery, Outbound Delivery, GR, GI), assign the SAP Remote type RFC destination that points to your non-SAP ERP gateway user.
  • In SM59, verify each RFC destination connects successfully.

Without these RFC entries, EWM doesn’t know how to hand off the GR to your ERP system.


3. (If Using IDocs) Maintain an ALE Distribution Model

If your integration uses IDocs instead of qRFCs:

  • In BD64 (Distribution Model), add a model view that connects your EWM logical system → your non-SAP ERP logical system.
  • Add the relevant message types (e.g. SHP_IBDLV_SAVE_REPLICA, MBGMCR).
  • Activate and generate the partner profile.


SAP Note 3140478 provides a how-to guide for IDoc integration with non-SAP ERP and decentralized EWM in S/4HANA.

entry.title: Re: Asset filed is not available in the import supplier i...
entry.content:
When you try to upload asset-related supplier invoices in the “Import Supplier Invoices” Fiori app (F3041), you’ll notice the Excel template only shows PO- and G/L-invoice fields by default. Unfortunately, you cannot permanently add custom columns to this delivered template—but there are a few ways to get your Asset Number into the upload.

1. Unhide the Asset Column in the Standard Template

  • Download the “Import Supplier Invoices” template for your chosen scenario (PO-based or G/L-based).
  • Right-click on the column headers in Excel and choose Unhide.
  • You’ll find hidden columns such as “Asset” (for asset acquisitions) and “Sub-number” tucked away.
  • Populate the Asset Number/Sub-number for each line and upload as usual.
  • The system reads these hidden fields and posts the invoice line(s) to the specified asset.

2. Switch to the G/L-Invoice Scenario

If your acquisition doesn’t require a PO, use the G/L Account Invoice scenario within the same app:

  • In F3041, select G/L Account instead of Purchase Order.
  • Download the G/L template—you’ll see an explicit “Asset” column exposed.
  • Fill in company code, document dates, G/L account, amount, and the Asset Number/Sub-number.
  • Upload to post directly to Asset Accounting via G/L invoices.

This avoids the PO-template’s hidden fields and gives you an open template with asset assignment.

3. Use the Asset Mass Processing App

For pure asset-side bulk processing (bypassing the AP invoice step), leverage the Upload Asset Details and Schedule Job for Asset Mass Processing Fiori apps:

  • Upload Asset Details - Download the Asset-mass-processing Excel template. Fill in Asset Master fields plus acquisition date, acquisition value, quantity, etc. Upload the file; it stages the data for processing.
  • Schedule Job for Asset Mass Processing - Trigger a background job to create assets with acquisition values in one go.

This is ideal for mass-creating assets and posting their acquisition values in Asset Accounting—though vendor invoices won’t be automatically cleared against these assets.
